description: From Middle English sunder, from Old English sundor- (“separate, different”), from Proto-Germanic *sundraz (“isolated, particular, alone”), from Proto-Indo-European *snter-, *seni-, *senu-, *san- (“apart, without, for oneself”). Cognate with Old Saxon sundar (“particular, special”), Dutch zonder (“without”), German sonder- (“special”), German sondern (“separate, set apart”), Old Norse sundr (“separate”), Danish sønder (“apart, asunder”), Latin sine (“without”).

adjectives.description: sunder (comparative more sunder, superlative most sunder)

description: From Middle English sundren (“to separate, part, divide”), from Old English sundrian (“to separate, split, part, divide”), from Proto-Germanic *sundrōną (“to separate”), from Proto-Indo-European *sen(e)- (“separate, without”). Cognate with Scots sinder, sunder (“to separate, divide, split up”), Dutch zonderen (“to isolate”), German sondern (“to separate”), Swedish söndra (“to divide”). More at sundry.

entries.meaning: a separation into parts; a division or severance
examples: He would not stay for me to stand and gaze.
I shook his hand and tore my heart in sunder
And went with half my life about my ways.

verbs.description: sunder (third-person singular simple present sunders, present participle sundering, simple past and past participle sundered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To break or separate or to break apart, especially with force.

examples: Two souls, the shores wave-mocked of sundering seas: —

entries.meaning: (UK, dialect, dated, transitive) To expose to the sun and wind.
